docs.title: SuperMaze Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the official SuperMaze documentation. This guide covers everything you need to know about the SuperMaze game engine, from getting started to advanced development.

docs.title: What is SuperMaze?
docs.text: SuperMaze is a procedurally-generated maze game built with vanilla HTML5, CSS3, and JavaScript. It features both singleplayer and multiplayer modes, with real-time player tracking, customizable themes, and a comprehensive settings system.

docs.title: Quick Navigation
docs.text:
• New to SuperMaze? Start with Getting Started
  • Want to play? Check out Quick Start
  • Need API details? See API Reference
  • Building a custom version? Read Development

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Dynamic maze generation with adjustable difficulty
  • Customizable theme system with personal backgrounds
  • Game settings editor with JSON support
  • Real-time multiplayer via WebSocket
  • Leaderboard with replay functionality
  • Experience points and level tracking
  • Secure input validation and authentication

docs.title: System Requirements
docs.text:
• Modern web browser (Chrome, Edge, Firefox, Safari)
  • Node.js 18+ (for multiplayer server)
  • No external dependencies required

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
• Check the FAQ section
  • Browse the complete API Reference
  • Visit the GitHub repository

docs.title: Latest Version
docs.text: SuperMaze v1.3.1

docs.title: Can I play offline?
docs.text: Yes! The singleplayer mode works completely offline. Your scores and progress are saved locally in your browser.

docs.title: How do I host a multiplayer server?
docs.text:
Install Node.js, navigate to src/server, and run: 

npm install
npm start

The server will run on http://localhost:3000

docs.title: Can I customize the maze difficulty?
docs.text: Yes! Use the Settings button in the game to adjust difficulty (Easy, Medium, Hard) and graphics quality (Low, Mid, High, Advanced).

docs.title: How are my scores saved?
docs.text: All your progress is saved locally in your browser's localStorage. No data is sent to external servers unless you choose to enable multiplayer.

docs.title: Can I create custom themes?
docs.text: Absolutely! Use the theme customization button to create themes with custom colors and background images.

docs.title: Is SuperMaze open source?
docs.text: Yes! Visit the GitHub repository for the full source code.

docs.title: Game Functions
docs.text: Core game function reference.

docs.title: generateMaze()
docs.text:
Generate new maze and place player/goal.

generateMaze();

docs.title: resetGame()
docs.text:
Reset game state for new maze.

resetGame();

docs.title: checkVictory()
docs.text:
Check if player reached goal.

checkVictory();

docs.title: saveRun(time)
docs.text:
Save completed run to leaderboard.

saveRun(45230); // time in milliseconds

docs.title: addXP(amount)
docs.text:
Award XP and update level.

addXP(50); // amount in XP points

docs.title: formatTime(ms)
docs.text:
Format milliseconds to MM:SS.MS.

formatTime(45230); // Returns "00:45.230"

docs.title: sanitizeUsername(name)
docs.text:
Clean and validate username.

sanitizeUsername("Player123"); // Returns sanitized name

docs.title: renderMaze()
docs.text:
Draw maze to screen.

renderMaze();

docs.title: playReplay(run)
docs.text:
Play back saved run.

playReplay(leaderboard[0]);

All functions are internal to index.html.

docs.title: Server Endpoints
docs.text: HTTP API reference for SuperMaze server.

docs.title: GET /leaderboard
docs.text:
Retrieve global leaderboard.

Response: 

[
  {"name": "Player1", "time": 45230, "date": "2026-01-16T10:30:00Z"},
  {"name": "Player2", "time": 67500, "date": "2026-01-16T10:25:00Z"}
]

Status Codes: - 200: Success - 500: Server error

docs.title: POST /leaderboard
docs.text:
Submit new leaderboard entry.

Request Body: 

{"name": "PlayerName", "time": 45230}

Response: 

{"success": true}

Status Codes: - 200: Entry saved - 400: Missing fields - 500: Server error

docs.title: WebSocket Endpoints
docs.text:
See WebSocket Events

Leaderboard API is simple and REST-based.

docs.title: Storage API Reference
docs.text: Client-side data storage keys and formats.

docs.title: localStorage Keys
docs.text: Key Type Description maze_username String Player username maze_auth_token String Auth token maze_xp Number Total XP maze_leaderboard JSON All runs maze_theme String Selected theme maze_custom_theme JSON Custom theme maze_game_settings JSON Game settings

docs.title: Reading Data
docs.text:
// Get username
const username = localStorage.getItem('maze_username');

// Get leaderboard
const leaderboard = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('maze_leaderboard'));

// Get settings
const settings = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('maze_game_settings'));

docs.title: Writing Data
docs.text:
// Save username
localStorage.setItem('maze_username', 'MyUsername');

// Save leaderboard
localStorage.setItem('maze_leaderboard', JSON.stringify(runs));

// Save settings
localStorage.setItem('maze_game_settings', JSON.stringify(settings));

docs.title: WebSocket Events
docs.text: Real-time communication protocol for multiplayer.

docs.title: auth
docs.text:
Authenticate with server.

{"type": "auth", "token": "user_abc123_1673872800000"}

docs.title: join
docs.text:
Send username to server.

{"type": "join", "username": "PlayerName"}

docs.title: move
docs.text:
Send player position.

{"type": "move", "x": 5, "y": 10}

docs.title: players
docs.text:
Broadcast all connected players.

{
  "type": "players",
  "players": [
    {"username": "Player1", "x": 1, "y": 1, "token": "user_..."},
    {"username": "Player2", "x": 5, "y": 10, "token": "user_..."}
  ],
  "timestamp": 1673872800000
}

docs.title: auth_ok
docs.text:
Authentication successful.

{"type": "auth_ok", "message": "Authenticated"}

docs.title: auth_error
docs.text:
Authentication failed.

{"type": "auth_error", "message": "Invalid token"}

Messages use JSON format over WebSocket.

docs.title: Settings Reference
docs.text: Complete guide to all SuperMaze settings.

docs.title: Difficulty
docs.text:
• Type: String
  • Values: "easy", "medium", "hard"
  • Default: "medium"
  • Effect: Affects maze complexity and size

docs.title: Graphics
docs.text:
• Type: String
  • Values: "low", "mid", "high", "advanced"
  • Default: "mid"
  • Effect: Visual quality and performance

docs.title: Storage Format
docs.text:
Settings stored in localStorage as key maze_game_settings:

{
  "difficulty": "medium",
  "graphics": "mid"
}

docs.title: Accessing Settings
docs.text:
From browser console:

// Get current settings
const settings = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('maze_game_settings'));
console.log(settings);

// Modify settings
settings.difficulty = "hard";
localStorage.setItem('maze_game_settings', JSON.stringify(settings));

docs.title: Theme Settings
docs.text:
Also stored in localStorage:

  • Key: maze_theme - Current theme name
  • Key: maze_custom_theme - Custom theme data

Settings are loaded automatically on game start.

docs.title: Code Style
docs.text: SuperMaze code style guidelines.

docs.title: Naming Conventions
docs.text:
• Variables: camelCase
  • Functions: camelCase
  • Constants: UPPER_SNAKE_CASE
  • Classes: PascalCase

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
// Variables
const playerPosition = { x: 0, y: 0 };
let currentScore = 0;

// Functions
function generateMaze() { }
const calculateDistance = () => { };

// Constants
const MAX_PLAYERS = 50;
const GRID_SIZE = 21;

// Objects/Classes
class MazeGenerator { }
const config = { };

docs.title: File Organization
docs.text:
• One logical component per file
  • Clear file naming
  • Group related functions
  • Export clear interfaces

docs.title: Comments
docs.text:
• Comment complex algorithms
  • Explain "why", not "what"
  • Keep comments updated
  • Use /* */ for blocks, // for lines

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
// Good: Explains the purpose
// Recursive backtracking generates perfect mazes
function generateMaze() { }

// Avoid: States the obvious
// This function generates a maze
function generateMaze() { }

docs.title: Function Size
docs.text:
• Keep functions focused
  • Max ~50 lines recommended
  • Single responsibility
  • Easy to test

docs.title: Variable Scope
docs.text:
• Use const by default
  • Use let when needed
  • Avoid var
  • Minimize scope

docs.title: Indentation
docs.text:
• 2 spaces (not tabs)
  • Consistent throughout
  • Match existing code

docs.title: HTML
docs.text:
• Semantic elements
  • Proper nesting
  • Meaningful IDs/classes
  • Accessibility attributes

docs.title: CSS
docs.text:
• kebab-case for class names
  • Related properties grouped
  • Comments for sections
  • Avoid inline styles

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
<!-- Good -->
<button id="play-btn" class="btn btn-primary">Play</button>

<!-- Avoid -->
<button id="playBtn" class="BTN BLUE">Play</button>

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
• Try-catch for risky operations
  • Meaningful error messages
  • Log errors to console
  • Handle gracefully

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
try {
  const data = JSON.parse(jsonString);
  return data;
} catch (error) {
  console.error('Failed to parse JSON:', error);
  return null;
}

docs.title: Security
docs.text:
• Always sanitize user input
  • Validate all data
  • Never use eval()
  • Use proper encoding

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
• Document complex functions
  • Include parameter descriptions
  • Note return types
  • Add examples

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
/**
 * Calculate distance between two points
 * @param {Object} p1 - First point {x, y}
 * @param {Object} p2 - Second point {x, y}
 * @returns {number} Distance between points
 */
function distance(p1, p2) {
  // ...
}

Follow these guidelines to keep SuperMaze code clean and maintainable.

docs.title: Game Settings
docs.text: Customize your SuperMaze experience with adjustable settings.

docs.title: Accessing Settings
docs.text: Click the Settings button (gear icon) on the home screen to open the settings modal.

docs.title: Difficulty Level
docs.text:
Adjust game difficulty:

Setting Description Effect Easy Smaller, simpler mazes Faster completion, less XP Medium Standard 21x21 maze Default balanced mode Hard Larger, complex mazes Slower completion, more challenge

docs.title: Graphics Mode
docs.text:
Optimize visual quality:

Mode Quality Performance Best For Low Minimal effects Fastest Older devices Mid Balanced (default) Smooth Most users High Enhanced effects Good Modern devices Advanced Maximum effects Intensive High-end systems

docs.title: Settings Editor
docs.text:
The JSON editor allows direct configuration:

{
  "difficulty": "medium",
  "graphics": "mid"
}

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Line numbers for easy reference
  • Syntax highlighting (basic)
  • Live dropdown synchronization
  • JSON validation before save
  • Error messages on invalid input

docs.title: Editing Tips
docs.text:
1. Edit either dropdown or JSON
  2. Changes sync automatically
  3. Press "Save & Exit" to confirm
  4. Invalid JSON shows error message
  5. Required fields: difficulty and graphics

docs.title: Custom Settings
docs.text:
Add custom fields to JSON:

{
  "difficulty": "hard",
  "graphics": "high",
  "playerName": "Champion",
  "colorScheme": "dark"
}

Custom fields are preserved when saving but don't affect gameplay (for now).

docs.title: Persistence
docs.text:
Settings are saved to localStorage:

  • Key: maze_game_settings
  • Format: JSON string
  • Loaded automatically on startup
  • Valid until manually changed or cleared

docs.title: Resetting Settings
docs.text:
To reset to defaults:

  1. Open Settings
  2. Edit JSON to: 
    {
  "difficulty": "medium",
  "graphics": "mid"
}
  3. Click "Save & Exit"

docs.title: Validation Rules
docs.text:
Settings must include:

  • ✓ difficulty: easy, medium, or hard
  • ✓ graphics: low, mid, high, or advanced
  • ✓ Valid JSON syntax
  • ✗ No missing required fields
  • ✗ No invalid values

docs.title: Per-Difficulty Settings
docs.text:
Plan to support in future:

{
  "difficulty": "hard",
  "graphics": "high",
  "difficultySettings": {
    "easy": {"mazeSize": 15},
    "medium": {"mazeSize": 21},
    "hard": {"mazeSize": 30}
  }
}

docs.title: Per-Graphics Settings
docs.text:
Potential future configuration:

{
  "graphics": "high",
  "graphicsSettings": {
    "low": {"shadowDepth": 0, "animations": false},
    "high": {"shadowDepth": 2, "animations": true}
  }
}

docs.title: Settings Won't Save
docs.text:
1. Check browser localStorage is enabled
  2. Ensure valid JSON syntax
  3. Verify required fields present
  4. Check browser console for errors

docs.title: Settings Not Loading
docs.text:
1. Check localStorage hasn't been cleared
  2. Try opening Settings again
  3. Verify valid JSON in localStorage
  4. Reset to defaults if corrupted

docs.title: Changes Not Applied
docs.text:
1. Restart the game
  2. Close and reopen browser
  3. Check Settings shows correct values
  4. Verify JSON editor matches dropdowns

Master your settings to tailor SuperMaze to your preferences!

docs.title: Leaderboard
docs.text: Track and compete with your best maze times.

docs.title: Accessing the Leaderboard
docs.text: Click the "Leaderboard" button on the home screen to view all your completed runs.

docs.title: View All Runs
docs.text: See every maze you've completed with: - Username - Completion time - Date played - Sorted by fastest time

docs.title: Replay Any Run
docs.text: Click on any leaderboard entry to: - Watch your exact moves - See your completion time - Review your performance - Learn from past attempts

docs.title: Run Information
docs.text:
Each leaderboard entry contains:

Field Description Username Player name from login Time MM:SS.MS format Date When completed Moves Complete move history

docs.title: Time Format
docs.text:
Times display in MM:SS.MS format:

  • MM = Minutes (00-59)
  • SS = Seconds (00-59)
  • MS = Milliseconds (000-999)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• 00:45.230 = 45 seconds, 230 milliseconds
  • 02:15.600 = 2 minutes, 15 seconds, 600 milliseconds
  • 01:00.000 = 1 minute exactly

docs.title: Sorting
docs.text:
Leaderboard automatically sorts by:

  1. Fastest Time First

docs.title: Maze Generation
docs.text: Learn how SuperMaze generates unique and solvable mazes.

docs.title: Algorithm
docs.text: SuperMaze uses the Recursive Backtracking algorithm (also known as Depth-First Search carving) to generate mazes.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Start with a grid of all walls
  2. Pick a random cell as the current cell
  3. Mark current cell as passage
  4. While there are unvisited neighbors:
  5. Pick a random unvisited neighbor
  6. Remove the wall between current and neighbor
  7. Make neighbor the current cell
  8. Recursively repeat
  9. Backtrack when no unvisited neighbors exist

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
• Guaranteed Solvable: Always has at least one path to the goal
  • Unique Mazes: No two mazes are identical (random generation)
  • Perfect Mazes: No loops or isolated areas
  • Deterministic: Algorithm always completes successfully

docs.title: Step 1: Initialize Grid
docs.text:
All cells start as walls (solid gray)
Size: 21x21 (configurable)

docs.title: Step 2: Carve Passages
docs.text:
Recursively carve passages between cells
Creates corridors and open areas

docs.title: Step 3: Place Player and Goal
docs.text:
Player: Random cell in upper-left area (red)
Goal: Random cell in lower-right area (green)
Guaranteed to be in open passage

docs.title: Step 4: Render Maze
docs.text:
Display to player with current theme colors
Ready for gameplay

docs.title: Difficulty Levels
docs.text:
Difficulty affects maze generation complexity:

Level Size Complexity Avg. Time Easy Small Simple paths 1-2 min Medium 21x21 Balanced 3-5 min Hard Large Complex 6+ min

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
• Generation Time: <100ms for 21x21 maze
  • Memory: ~10KB per maze
  • Renderability: Instant (pre-computed)

docs.title: Customization
docs.text:
Modify maze generation in index.html:

// Maze size (currently 21)
const size = 21;

// Cell size in pixels
const cellPx = 25;

// Generation function
function generateMaze() {
  // Modify algorithm here
}

docs.title: Algorithm Complexity
docs.text:
• Time: O(N²) where N is grid size
  • Space: O(N²) for maze storage
  • Recursion Depth: O(N²) in worst case

docs.title: Variations
docs.text:
SuperMaze uses the basic recursive backtracking algorithm. Other algorithms include:

  • Prim's Algorithm: Similar results, different approach
  • Kruskal's Algorithm: Another minimum spanning tree method
  • Hunt and Kill: Iterative alternative
  • Binary Tree: Faster but less balanced

docs.title: Guarantees
docs.text:
Every generated maze has:

  • ✓ Exactly one solution (non-branching)
  • ✓ Player always reachable from goal
  • ✓ No unreachable areas
  • ✓ No loops or circles
  • ✓ Unique layout each time

The maze generation makes every game unique and challenging!

docs.title: Server Architecture
docs.text:
Express HTTP Server (Port 3000)
├── Leaderboard API
│   ├── GET /leaderboard
│   └── POST /leaderboard
├── Static Files
│   └── public/
└── WebSocket Server
    ├── Authentication
    ├── Player Management
    └── Broadcasting

docs.title: Data Flow
docs.text:
Client 1
   │
   ├─── Move (x, y) ──┐
   │                  │
   │         WebSocket Server
   │                  │
   │    Broadcasts ───┤
   │    all players   │
   │                  │
Client 2 ◄────────────┘
   │
   └─── Receives Player1 position

docs.title: Optimization Tips

docs.title: Your First Game
docs.text: A detailed walkthrough of playing your first SuperMaze game.

docs.title: Before You Start
docs.text: Make sure you have: - SuperMaze open in your browser - Entered a username and logged in - Selected your game mode (Singleplayer or Multiplayer)

docs.title: Game Screen Overview
docs.text:
When you start a game, you'll see:

  • Maze Grid: The game area with corridors and walls
  • Red Cell: Your player position (starting point)
  • Green Cell: The goal/end point
  • Gray Walls: Obstacles you cannot pass through
  • White Passages: Open corridors you can move through
  • Stopwatch: Time counter in the top-right
  • Keystrokes Display: Shows which keys you're pressing (bottom-left)

docs.title: Step 1: Understand the Layout
docs.text: Take a moment to observe the maze: - Locate your position (red cell) - Find the goal (green cell) - Identify nearby passages and walls

docs.title: Step 2: First Movement
docs.text: Press W or Up Arrow to move forward. You should move one cell in that direction.

docs.title: Step 3: Navigate to the Goal
docs.text: Use the movement controls to navigate: - Move cautiously to explore the maze - Turn left and right to find open paths - Avoid dead ends when possible - Work toward the green goal cell

docs.title: Step 4: Complete the Maze
docs.text: When you reach the green cell, the game automatically: 1. Stops your timer 2. Records your completion time 3. Awards you 50 XP 4. Saves the run to your leaderboard 5. Shows a victory screen

docs.title: Victory Screen
docs.text:
After completing a maze, you'll see:

  • Your completion time
  • Option to "Replay Run" - watch your recorded moves
  • Option to "Return to Menu" - play another maze

docs.title: Time Measurement
docs.text:
Time is displayed in MM:SS.MS format: - MM = Minutes - SS = Seconds - MS = Milliseconds

Example: 02:35.450 = 2 minutes, 35 seconds, 450 milliseconds

docs.title: Time Benchmarks
docs.text:
• Expert: Under 2 minutes
  • Advanced: 2-4 minutes
  • Intermediate: 4-6 minutes
  • Beginner: 6+ minutes

Don't worry about speed on your first game - focus on learning the controls!

docs.title: Tips for Your First Game
docs.text:
1. Use Systematic Exploration: Try moving in one direction until you hit a wall, then try another direction
  2. Map Mentally: Remember sections of the maze you've explored
  3. Avoid Backtracking: Try not to return to areas you've already been
  4. Stay Calm: Take your time - speed comes with practice
  5. Watch the Stopwatch: Use it to track your progress

docs.title: Mistake 1: Panic in Dead Ends
docs.text: What to do: Calmly backtrack and try a different path. You can move in any direction with arrows/WASD.

docs.title: Mistake 2: Losing Orientation
docs.text: What to do: Stop moving and look at the maze structure. The green goal cell is always visible.

docs.title: Mistake 3: Trying to Climb Walls
docs.text: What to do: Walls are impassable. You must find corridors around them.

docs.title: Mistake 4: Using Wrong Controls
docs.text: What to do: Remember: WASD = arrow keys. Only these 4 inputs work. Make sure you're not typing elsewhere.

docs.title: View Your Results
docs.text:
1. After victory, click "Return to Menu"
  2. Click "Leaderboard" or "Saved Replays"
  3. Your run appears in the list with:
  4. Username
  5. Completion time
  6. Date played

docs.title: Watch Your Replay
docs.text:
1. Open Leaderboard or Saved Replays
  2. Click on your run
  3. Watch your moves play back automatically

docs.text:
• Play more mazes to learn patterns
  • Challenge yourself on harder difficulties
  • Adjust graphics for better visibility
  • Compare times with previous runs

docs.title: Common Questions
docs.text:
Q: Can I pause the game? - A: No, but you can close the browser tab and resume later (your progress in-maze is saved)

Q: What happens if I click "Exit"? - A: Your current run is abandoned and you return to the menu. Progress is not saved.

Q: Can I play the same maze twice? - A: No, a new maze is generated each time. Mazes are always unique.

Q: Why is my time so slow? - A: This is normal for your first game! Speed improves with practice.

Q: How do I replay a specific run? - A: Open the Leaderboard, find the run, and click on it to watch the replay.

Congratulations on completing your first SuperMaze game! Ready for a new challenge?

docs.text:
1. You start at the red cell (top-left area)
  2. Navigate through the white passages
  3. Avoid walls (dark gray)
  4. Reach the green cell (end) to complete the maze
  5. Your time is recorded automatically
  6. View your run on the leaderboard

docs.title: Main Menu Buttons
docs.text:
• Singleplayer: Start a new maze game
  • Saved Replays: View past runs and watch replays
  • Theme Dropdown: Change the visual theme
  • Customize (+): Create custom themes with colors and images
  • Leaderboard: View all your completed runs
  • Settings: Adjust difficulty, graphics, and advanced options
  • Docs: Open this documentation
  • Logout: Sign out and switch accounts

docs.title: Settings
docs.text:
Click the Settings button (⚙️) to customize:

  • Difficulty: Easy, Medium, or Hard
  • Graphics: Low, Mid, High, or Advanced
  • Custom Settings: Edit JSON directly

docs.title: Tips for Playing
docs.text:
1. Learn the Controls: Practice moving smoothly through corridors
  2. Explore Slowly: Take time to map out the maze mentally
  3. Watch Your Time: Challenge yourself to complete faster runs
  4. Replay Runs: Click runs in the leaderboard to watch replays
  5. Customize Your Experience: Adjust difficulty and graphics for your preference

docs.title: Understanding Your Stats
docs.text:
• Level: Based on total XP (100 XP per level)
  • XP: Earn 50 XP per completed maze
  • Time: Your completion time for each run
  • Leaderboard: Shows your best runs sorted by time

docs.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text: Shortcut Action WASD or Arrows Move in maze Esc Not implemented (use Exit button)

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Explore Features to learn about advanced options
  • Read about Game Settings
  • Learn about Theme Customization
  • Check Multiplayer guide

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Q: The maze looks small/large - A: Adjust graphics mode in Settings

Q: My scores aren't saving - A: Check browser localStorage is enabled (Settings > Privacy)

Q: Can't move in the maze - A: Ensure you're not typing in an input field - A: Try clicking the maze area first

Q: Want to change username - A: Click the Logout button, then enter a new username

Ready to dive deeper? Check out the Features section!

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text: How SuperMaze secures user sessions.

docs.title: Token Format
docs.text:
user_XXXXX_TIMESTAMP
user_abc123_1673872800000

docs.title: Token Generation
docs.text:
authToken = "user_" + Math.random().toString(36).slice(2, 9) + "_" + Date.now();
localStorage.setItem("maze_auth_token", authToken);

docs.title: Server Validation
docs.text:
function validateToken(token) {
  return token && typeof token === "string" && token.startsWith("user_");
}

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
• Must start with "user_"
  • Must be non-empty string
  • Must be stored in localStorage
  • Validated on every connection

docs.title: WebSocket Authentication
docs.text:
1. Client connects to WebSocket
  2. Client sends auth message with token
  3. Server validates token format
  4. Server stores authenticated connection
  5. Only authenticated clients can move

docs.title: Session Management
docs.text:
• Tokens persist across page refreshes
  • Each browser gets unique token
  • Clearing localStorage clears auth
  • No server-side session storage

docs.title: Security Guarantees
docs.text:
• No passwords transmitted
  • No external auth servers
  • Tokens are ephemeral
  • Session-based only
  • localStorage access only

Authentication is simple, local, and secure.

docs.title: Data Protection
docs.text: How SuperMaze protects user data.

docs.title: Client Data
docs.text:
All user data stays local:

  • Username
  • Auth tokens
  • XP and level
  • Leaderboard
  • Settings
  • Theme preferences

No external servers access this data unless multiplayer is enabled.

docs.title: Server Data
docs.text:
Server only stores:

  • Public leaderboard (name + time)
  • Active player positions (temporary)
  • Game settings (if shared)

No sensitive data on server.

docs.title: localStorage Storage
docs.text:
• Survives page refreshes
  • Survives browser restarts
  • Cleared only by user action
  • No expiration time

docs.title: Server Storage
docs.text:
• Player data stored in memory
  • Leaderboard stored in JSON files
  • No database used
  • Data persists across restarts

docs.title: XSS Prevention
docs.text:
• All user input sanitized
  • HTML entities encoded
  • Safe DOM manipulation
  • No eval() used

docs.title: Input Validation
docs.text:
• Usernames limited to 32 chars
  • URLs validated before use
  • Colors restricted to hex format
  • JSON safely parsed with error handling

docs.title: Safe Communication
docs.text:
• WebSocket validates messages
  • Invalid messages rejected
  • No code execution allowed
  • Type checking on all inputs

docs.title: What Stays Local
docs.text:
• Player passwords (not used)
  • Personal settings
  • Game statistics
  • Play history

docs.title: What Can Be Shared
docs.text:
• Username
  • Best times
  • Leaderboard rankings
  • Public statistics

docs.title: Reset Everything
docs.text:
localStorage.clear();
location.reload();

docs.title: Clear Specific Data
docs.text:
localStorage.removeItem('maze_leaderboard');
localStorage.removeItem('maze_xp');
localStorage.removeItem('maze_username');

Your data is your own and stays local unless you enable multiplayer.

docs.title: Input Validation
docs.text: How SuperMaze secures user inputs.

docs.title: Sanitization
docs.text:
function sanitizeUsername(name) {
  return String(name)
    .replace(/[<>\"'&`]/g, "")
    .substring(0, 32)
    .trim();
}

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
• Max 32 characters
  • Remove HTML special characters
  • Trim whitespace
  • Block script tags

docs.title: Sanitization
docs.text:
function sanitizeUrl(url) {
  if (!url) return "";
  const trimmed = String(url).trim();
  if (trimmed.toLowerCase().startsWith("javascript:")) return "";
  if (trimmed.toLowerCase().startsWith("data:")) return "";
  try {
    new URL(trimmed);
    return trimmed;
  } catch {
    return "";
  }
}

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
• Reject javascript: protocol
  • Reject data: protocol
  • Validate URL syntax
  • Return empty if invalid

docs.title: Sanitization
docs.text:
function sanitizeColor(color) {
  const match = String(color).match(/^#([0-9a-f]{6}|[0-9a-f]{3})$/i);
  return match ? match[0] : "#000000";
}

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
• Accept hex format only
  • Accept 6 or 3-digit hex
  • Return black if invalid
  • Case-insensitive

docs.title: Sanitization
docs.text:
function sanitizeJSON(jsonString) {
  try {
    const parsed = JSON.parse(jsonString);
    if (typeof parsed !== "object") return null;
    return parsed;
  } catch {
    return null;
  }
}

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
• Try parse JSON
  • Check is object type
  • Return null if invalid
  • Never execute code

All inputs are validated before use.
